We are committed to publishing a White Paper giving details of how we propose to implement the undertakings we gave last year (in the white paper Cmnd 5732 and in our election manifestos) to set up elected assemblies for Scotland and Wales, and to devolve extensive powers tothem.2. I attach the draft of the White Paper. It reflects the intensiveprogramme of work, involving all Departments, carried out during the past year under the supervision of the Ministerial Steering Committee onDevolution (DS). I have taken account of comments sent to me since thelast DS discussion.3. My colleagues may wish to note in particular paragraphs 5 and 288,which make clear that the proposals are open to debate and detailedmodification; and paragraph 6, which makes clear that we do not plan to legislate in haste.4. Passages relating to the role of the House of Lords in "override"procedures and to future responsibility for the probation service in Walesare in square brackets pending discussion by the Ministerial Committee onDevolution Questions (DQM) on 7 November. I shall report the outcome tothe Cabinet separately.5. I envisage that the White Paper, if approved by the Cabinet, would bepublished on Thursday, 27 November. It will be published simultaneously in Welsh. The main White Paper will be followed by a popular version, tobe distributed free through public libraries and post offices.1 6. The Secretary of State for the Environment and I will be puttingproposals to the Cabinet in other papers on the publication of a discussiondocument about devolution in England.7. A healthy democracy is a living and developing system. Our democraticinstitutions have been admirably stable, but that does not mean that they areperfect and unchangeable. In particular, over a lengthy period centralgovernment has accumulated an array of powers and functions some of which couldbe exercised at a lower level, closer to the people. The case for this isespecially strong in Scotland and Wales, where there remains a sense ofhistorical identity included within, but distinct from, the consciousness ofbeing British. This was the philosophy which underlay the decision announced by the Government in a White Paper* in September 1974 to set up elected assemblies in Scotland and Wales.2. The 1974 decision to devolve certain governmental responsibilities to scottish and Welsh assemblies, which flowed from a determination to bringdemocratic authority to bear more closely on policy and administration inthese countries, was taken after wide public discussion on a consultative document, and clearly met the aspirations of the majority of Scots and Welsh.That decision was however only the beginning. The constitutional change proposed is the most fundamental of its kind in Great Britain for centuries.It would have been folly to propose hasty and over-simplified answers to detailed and complex problems. The task the Government set themselveshad few previous parallels in any country, namely the division between twolevels of Government of the powers and functions exercised centrally in a unitary state. The new system must work efficiently as well as democratically,and it must stand the test of time.3. The White Paper of September 1974 indicated in general terms the rolesand powers that Assemblies for Scotland and Wales would have and the subjectareas in which they would operate. This White Paper turns those general principles into detailed proposals. It explains how the relations of thenew structures with the Government would work, what subject areas would be devolved, how continuing United Kingdom interests would be looked after, and how the financial principles outlined in the earlier White Paper would be implemented. The proposals rest on intensive studies of great range and1* Democracy and Devolution:Proposals for Scotland and Wales (Cmnd 5732) (confsdemt8al) Jcomplexity. The activities of every G-overnment department have beer,examined in detail to establish how devolution should affect them. There!have been studies of the involved economic problems relating to expenditrand taxation by devolved administrations. Nor could each study proceed!isolation; the preferred solution in one area of governmental activity s-.interact with those in others, and great care has been necessary to ensurethat the final proposals form a consistent package.4. The G-overnment believe that this White Paper sets out coherent andworkable proposals which provide a sound basis for legislation to set upelected Assemblies in Scotland and Wales. The implementation of theseproposals should make government in Scotland and Wales less remote, more Iopen, and more responsive to the needs and desires of the people - and hencmore effective. It will help to preserve and foster the distinctivenational traditions of Scotland and Wales, which everyone in the UnitedKingdom should value as part of our common heritage. The proposals givepractical recognition to the differing needs and desires of the peoples o!Scotland and Wales, and thus should both reassure them that their wishescan never be overlooked and help to preserve the unity as well as thediversity of the United Kingdom.5. The Government recognise however that these proposals raise issues o! jgreat significance for all the people of the United Kingdom. Two issues are of particular importance - getting a sound and stabledistribution of responsibilities between Westminster and the devolvedadministrations; and ensuring that the proposals meet the reasonable neeof Scotland and Wales, while maintaining a fair balance between theinterests of those territories and of the rest of the United Kingdom,Achieving this has naturally resulted in many complex, detailed and speci Iprovisions that could not have been identified at the time of the earlierWhite Paper. The Government now want to see full public and Parliamentsconsideration, because of the extreme importance of the issues for allth jpeople of the United Kingdom; the novelty of the arrangements proposed;and the need, in constitutional matters, to get right first time the essentials of legislation that will inevitably be complicated. The mainstructure of the schemes is clear, but they need not represent the lastword in every respect. The Government will accordingly be very willing2 to listen to representations about their proposals which are consistent withthe. approach set out in Part II of this White Paper.6. Work is in hand on drafting a Bill, which will take accountprogressively of points made during consultation. It will be published as early as possible in the spring of 1976. It would not however be feasible then to carry so major a Bill through to Royeil Assent in the1975/76 session. Moreover, the Government believe that it would be wrong to legislate in haste on issues of such very special and lastingconstitutional importance. The Bill, when published, will provide theopportunity for debate and for focussing opinion more closely on specificlegislative proposals; and the Government will take account of all this in further refining the schemes. They will then introduce a Bill inParliament at the start of the following session.7. Maintaining the integrity of the United Kingdom does not entail uniformtreatment for all its parts. This White Paper is about devolution to scotland and Wales, and its proposals are related to their needs. Asthe White Paper of September 1974 made clear, Northern Ireland comes into adifferent category. Its history and geography distinguish it from otherparts of the United Kingdom, as does the presence of two separate communities.Its problems are not those of Scotland or Wales, and therefore do notnecessarily require the same treatment. England is different again, andthe Government will publish separately a discussion document on the way-forward there.8. Part III sets out the scheme for Scotland and Part TV thescheme for Wales; to make each reasonably self-contained, there is inevitably a good deal of repetition between them. ' The Government believe however that something more is needed - the creationof elected as well as administrative institutions distinctive to Scotland andWales. This is what devolution means. There will be new democratic bodies,directly chosen by and answerable to the Scottish and Welsh people for very wide areas of government business. Decision talcing in the devolved matters will bebrought closer to the people, and the lines of democratic accountability willbe shorter and more responsive to their wishes.15. The central task on which the Government has concentrated in developing the devolution schemes is to define those areas of activity where decisions affectprimarily people living in Scotland and Wales. It would be plainly wrong todevolve to the new Scottish and Welsh Assemblies powers over activities whichsubstantially affect people outside Scotland or Wales, or the well-being of theUnited Kingdom generally. The need is to achieve balance - to reconcile unity and diversity in a stronger and better system, offering more achievement andsatisfaction to the parts whilst improving the efficiency and stability of thewhole. In working this out the Government have observed the principles whichflow from acceptance of the essential unity of the United Kingdom. They have alsokept in mind the need for a consistent and coherent pattern of government, whichwill be clear and understandable to the public whom it serves and the people who work in it. Throughout the Governments consideration of their proposals,the key criterion has been the long-term advantage of the people of Scotland andWales within a unified British state.16. Under the Governments proposals, the Assemblies will control policies andspending prioritj.es in a very wide range of services, including for example mostaspects of local government, health, personal social services, educa/fcion, housing,physical planning, the environment and roads, and many aspects of transport. TheScottish Assembly will also be able to make new laws or amend present ones in thesematters, and since it will be a legislative body it can be given responsibility in addition for most aspects of the distinctive private and criminal law ofScotland.I?. All these powers will enable the new Scottish and Welsh administrations tobring very great influence to bear on the whole physical and social environment5 it/of their countries. That influence, together with the large spending power which the administrations xvi 11 directly control will enable them to have a veimarked effect also on their economic environment In addition, they will beable to debate economic matters and frame proposals for discussion XV ITH theGovernment,18. In particular the Government must be able to do what exis needed for national security; they must conduct international relations,including those flowing from our membership of the European Community; and themust maintain the national framework of Law and order, guaranteeing the basicrights of the citizen throughout the United Kingdom. Political unity also uesthat British citizens are at home throughout the United Kingdom; the Scotsmanand the Welshman living and working in London as much as the Englishman living and working in Edinburgh or Cardiff.20. Economic unity plainly means that the Government must manage the nation^external economic relations - the balance of payments, the exchange rate, extassets and liabilities, and economic, trading and. other arrangements with oticountries. But the principle has to go much further. The Government must beto manage demand in the economy as a whole - to control national taxation, to'public expenditure and the supply of money and credit. Against this background the Government have studied with great care howfar the new administrations could be given direct powers over the economy in Scotland and Wales since this is a matter of great importance to both countries. They have had to conclude that the scope for this kind of devolution is strictly limited by the fundamental needs of unity. Pulleconomic autonomy would mean abandoning the basic United Kingdom approach,which all governments have adopted for decades past.22. Our people are less and less ready to tolerate extremes of wealth andpoverty alongside one another in our society. This applies betweengeographical areas, not just between individuals. Unplanned, economic forces,changes in world demand and the discovery of new natural resources can bringfortune or misfortune to large areas, and over the centuries almost every partof the United Kingdom has experienced this ebb and flow. In recent timessuccessive Governments have increasingly sought to diminish inequalities;the fact that Scotland and Wales, like Northern Ireland, are at presentclassified in their entirety as assisted areas is evidence of this.23. Regional policies have been formulated and implemented for the UnitedKindgom as a whole, and only in that way can true priorities be judged and theresources of the whole country be deployed to help solve problems as they arise anywhere within it. Nor would it be practicable simply to leave particular areas to draw up their own schemes of economic support and. assistance within an overall allocation of funds, since divergences in approach would inevitablyresult in distortions of. competition which could not be accommodated within a unified economy. For these reasons it is not possible to give the new scottish and Welsh administrations substantial direct economic powers.24. The powers to be devolved will nevertheless enable the Assemblies to havemarked influence on the economic environment of Scotland and Wales. Thearrangements for the Scottish and Welsh Development Agencies described in njtiaOparagraphs 134 and 245 respectively will give the Assemblies an importantrole in the work of these new bodies, which are intended to give a newstimulus to industrial and environmental regeneration. At the same timethe transfer of manpower functions - so crucial to economic development -add an important new dimension to the decision making in the economic fieldcarried out in Scotland and Wales.24A. The complete schemes for Scotland and Wales are set out in Parts III iand IV respectively. They are designed to give maximum freedom to the newadministrations in domestic matters whilst preserving the United Kingdomdimensions where it is needed. But the Government do not contemplate a future in which, once the new system is set up, they and the administrationswill deal with one another at arm's length. Every effort will be made inadvance to cut our overlap and uncertainty, and to avoid the problems whichill-defined relationships would cause; but there will be many matters on whichcontinuing close contacts will be in the common interest.24B. Arrangements for extensive but flexible consultation will be required on many subjects and at all levels, political and official. Through these theGovernment and the devolved administrations will keep one another informed anawill work together as closely as possible. Interests will sometimes differ, agive and take will be needed. But the Government see no reason to fear thatthe longstanding spirit of partnership within the United Kingdom vail be replaby confrontation. They look forward to working out effective two-wayconsultation arrangements with the devolved administrations as soon as possiViand to operating them over the years in a spirit of goodwill and co-operation24C. Ever since the voluntary union of Scotland and England in 1707 thearrangements for the government of Scotland have differed in some respect:; fK.those for England. In modern times these arrangements have centred on theoffice of the Secretary of State for Scotland. A Secretary for Scotland was created in 1885, but the present system dates effectively from the opening in1939 of St Andrew's House in Edinburgh. It gives to the Secretary-of State,who is a member of the Cabinet, a wide range of responsibilities for theadministration of government in Scotland. These include most of the functions which in England are the responsibility of the Home Office, the Department ofEducation and Science, the Department of the Environment, the Ministry ofAgriculture, Fisheries and Food and the health and personal social service sids Iof the Department of Health and Social Security, as well as (more recently)some functions of the Department of Industry. In addition, the Lord Advocate as Ia Scottish Minister within the United Kingdom Government has always had widefunctions in the field of law.26. This system has achieved much for Scotland. It gives Scotland a strongvoice in the Cabinet and separate representation on interdepartmental committee\where policy options are worked out. The Government intend that there should remain major roles for the Secretary of State and the Lord Advocate, as Part V jof this White Paper shows. Bat the present system, based on Westminster withits wider burdens, cannot always allow responsively enough for distinctively JScottish problems and Scottish characteristics. Factors like these have be cob\more significant as the scope of government business and the calls on Parliameiltime have grown.27. Many features of the constitutional scheme proposed are modelled onParliament, where they are well tried and have evolved over the centuries in apractical blend of efficient government and democratic rights. Parliament mustendow Scotland with a comparable blend. There will not be time before the Assembly comes into being for the Boundary Commission for Scotland to complete the thoroughscrutiny needed to divide the Parliamentary constituencies fairly.
